{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3572666,"name":"Rowan Flood","username":"rflood","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/7bcc69/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-30T00:54:46.565Z","cooked":"

Our team - 2491 NoMythic - just finished an awesome weekend of competing at the Minnesota 10,000 Lakes Regional. We did quite good, but it took us all of practice matches and most of quals to finally have coordinates that successfully placed coral every time on every reef side during our automatic score command (we use a PID loop to drive towards coordinates on the field).

For calibration, we placed the robot in front of the reef in the perfect scoring position, and wrote down the coordinates that our limelight read. We did this for every single reef pole, on red and blue, but we still had many poles that had to have their coordinates readjusted multiple times between matches, because they were missing. How do we get those positions perfectly calibrated during calibration time, or practice matches?
Any ideas from teams with very successful and consistent automated lineup?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2025-03-30T00:54:46.565Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":16,"reads":149,"readers_count":148,"score":109.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":497366,"topic_slug":"how-to-fully-calibrate-automatic-lineup-coordinates-during-auto","display_username":"Rowan Flood","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":73641,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/how-to-fully-calibrate-automatic-lineup-coordinates-during-auto/497366/1","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3572683,"name":"Doug Kavner","username":"dkavner","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/dkavner/{size}/207188_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-30T01:08:03.346Z","cooked":"

You probably aren’t ending your drive at the exact coordinates due to insufficient Kp or excessive Kd, possibly aggravated by some roll-out, even if you’re using brake mode. You should create a log on a practice field, preferably using a tool like AdvantageKit/AdvantageScope, so you can troubleshoot.

That’s a good idea, but we have advantageKit logging and can see that it reaches within 1.5 cm of the target every time (that’s also our tolerance for when we decide to shoot the coral)

My first in-person comp is next weekend but I’ve heard …doesn’t the reef move slightly and get repositioned by field staff occasionally?

So “perfect” is really a moving goal? For pure odometry.

I suppose vision to the local tags should correct better with any relative moment of the reef?

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2025-03-30T01:16:31.026Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":108,"readers_count":107,"score":46.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":497366,"topic_slug":"how-to-fully-calibrate-automatic-lineup-coordinates-during-auto","display_username":"Joseph Walters","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":54568,"username":"dkavner","name":"Doug Kavner","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/dkavner/{size}/207188_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":63541,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/how-to-fully-calibrate-automatic-lineup-coordinates-during-auto/497366/4","reactions":[{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3572701,"name":"Ethan Grieshop","username":"CakeDeer6","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cakedeer6/{size}/264680_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-30T01:21:03.290Z","cooked":"

A much easier way to do this is to use the official AprilTag coordinates from the game manual and apply a constant offset from each of them, changing only if you go to the left or right for each branch. This way, you only have to measure one set of coordinates, and you can apply the same translations from each AprilTag to get your lineup coordinates for each branch. The AprilTagFieldLayout class contains the base coordinates you need, and then you can use Transform2d to move left, right, forward, and backward from that given pose by whatever amount you want. It’s the solution my team chose, and it made things much easier for us.

It sounds like they are using Single Tag Alignment rather than Global Pose. Movement of the reef shouldn’t be an issue.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2025-03-30T01:21:18.852Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":89,"readers_count":88,"score":17.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":497366,"topic_slug":"how-to-fully-calibrate-automatic-lineup-coordinates-during-auto","display_username":"Doug Kavner","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":63541,"username":"Jwal","name":"Joseph Walters","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jwal/{size}/228161_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":54568,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/how-to-fully-calibrate-automatic-lineup-coordinates-during-auto/497366/6","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3572705,"name":"Ashton Demmer","username":"ashtondemmer","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ashtondemmer/{size}/230987_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-30T01:21:45.561Z","cooked":"

First, are you sure that your pid is tuned well? How close to your set point are you getting? We are running 3cm tolerance in x,y and are able to achieve that consistently. Also note that if you are auto aligning from close to your end goal vs far from your end goal the robot may respond differently if you don’t have solid pid values.

Second, are you using global pose estimation when aligning (using all apriltags in sight) or local (only looking at the tag on the reef) we prefer local because even if the reef were to get moved dramatically over the course of comp the pose would still be accurate. Also if you calibrate based on multitag in calibration period and then try it in a match, if one of the tags gets covered by another robot that can affect your pose estimation. For our comp a student wrote a python script that did the trig to calculate robot pose based off the known apriltag locations. With local estimation we never had to place the robot in front of a single scoring location and our set points were accurate throughout the event.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2025-03-30T01:21:45.561Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":89,"readers_count":88,"score":17.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":497366,"topic_slug":"how-to-fully-calibrate-automatic-lineup-coordinates-during-auto","display_username":"Ashton Demmer","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51932,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"6147 - Tonkabots"},"post_url":"/t/how-to-fully-calibrate-automatic-lineup-coordinates-during-auto/497366/7","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3572706,"name":"Rowan Flood","username":"rflood","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/7bcc69/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-30T01:21:57.731Z","cooked":"

We use global odometry, but reading all this I’m thinking it might be easier to switch to using aprilTag-relative alignment

Correction: we use global odometry but when in front of the reef can only see the AprilTags on that reef side

rflood:

it reaches within 1.5 cm of the target every time

By it do you mean the robot is where it is supposed to be but the reef isn’t there?

Jwal:

vision to the local tags should correct better with any relative moment of the reef

You’d have to use the robot-in-tag space pose otherwise the tag which thinks it knows where it’s supposed to be will be moved with the reef.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2025-03-30T01:23:24.162Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":2,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":71,"readers_count":70,"score":19.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":497366,"topic_slug":"how-to-fully-calibrate-automatic-lineup-coordinates-during-auto","display_username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24594,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/how-to-fully-calibrate-automatic-lineup-coordinates-during-auto/497366/10","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3572713,"name":"Rowan Flood","username":"rflood","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/7bcc69/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-30T01:26:13.260Z","cooked":"

“It” is the robots position from the odometer, which is updated by the April tags right in front of it. We have to change the coordinates because it goes to the correct coordinates, but it isn’t actually in the correct spot relative to the reef. This is confusing because we place the robot in the right spot during calibration and use those coordinates

You can verify that your estimated pose of odometry + vision pose is accurate by measuring the robot’s true position and comparing it to the estimated pose
